questions.text: Select the correct answer regarding the contributions of Hippocrates, Avicenna, and Joseph Lister: Hippocrates rejected the supernatural and divine forces as causes of illness. Avicenna’s The Canon of Medicine focused on surgery and antiseptic techniques. Joseph Lister introduced antiseptic techniques to prevent infection during surgery. Charaka’s Charaka Samhita emphasized surgical procedures and anesthetics.
Which of the following models of disease causation is depicted in the image below?

Match the Following: Column A (Institutes) Central Drug Research Institute National Tuberculosis Institute National AIDS Control Organisation National Institute of Nutrition Column B (Location) Lucknow Bengaluru New Delhi Hyderabad

A 35-year-old public health expert is tasked with comparing two countries' health and education outcomes. After reviewing various health indicators, including life expectancy at birth and infant mortality rate, she notes a country with a low HDI but a relatively higher PQLI. Which of the following statements best explains this discrepancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The country has a high literacy rate but low income levels.

options.label: B
options.text: The country has a low life expectancy at birth but a high life expectancy at 1 year of age.

options.label: C
options.text: The country has a high infant mortality rate but a higher gross enrollment ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: The country has a higher income but lower literacy rates.

questions.correct_answer: B. The country has a low life expectancy at birth but a high life expectancy at 1 year of age.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The country has a low life expectancy at birth but a high life expectancy at 1 year of age.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases would least benefit from Passive Surveillance due to its rapid progression and severity?

A newly developed health indicator is evaluated for its practical application in resource-limited settings. The indicator is easy to measure, requires minimal data collection, and can be implemented with available resources. Which characteristic of an ideal health indicator is being assessed here?
Match the following Diseases with their Longest Incubation periods: Diseases SARS Chicken pox Syphilis Hepatitis A Incubation period 21 days 90 days 50 days 10 days

A cohort study investigates the impact of high-fat diets on the development of colorectal cancer (CRC). The relative risk (RR) of CRC in individuals with high-fat diets compared to those with low-fat diets is 1.85. Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion based on this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: High-fat diets reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: High-fat diets increase the risk of colorectal cancer by 85%.

options.label: C
options.text: High-fat diets have no effect on colorectal cancer risk.

options.label: D
options.text: The study suggests that the relationship between diet and CRC is likely due to reverse causality.

questions.correct_answer: B. High-fat diets increase the risk of colorectal cancer by 85%.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) High-fat diets increase the risk of colorectal cancer by 85%.

questions.text: A clinician is reviewing several studies to make an informed decision about using a particular medication in her practice. One of the studies is a large cohort study that demonstrates an association between the medication and improved outcomes, while a smaller, randomized controlled trial (RCT) shows no significant benefit. Which principle of evidence-based medicine is the clinician most likely applying when weighing these different study designs?
Mr Mayitree Sarkar is 38-year-old male with single stellate hypopigmented skin lesion and thickening of nerve. Which dose is to be given under NLEP?
A 32-year-old HIV-positive patient with symptoms presents to a clinic for a vaccination. Which of the following vaccines is not contraindicated in this patient?
Which of the following vaccines is not subject to the Open Vial Policy for reuse after opening and must be destroyed if not used within 8 hours?
The CERVAVAC vaccine is developed to prevent cervical cancer caused by HPV. Which of the following is the manufacturer of CERVAVAC?
Which of the following is a misconception about the purpose of screening programs in the context of disease detection?

options.label: A
options.text: Screening programs are aimed at detecting diseases in apparently healthy individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: Screening tests are used to make definitive diagnoses and offer treatment plans.

options.label: C
options.text: Screening programs are primarily used to identify previously undiagnosed diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: Screening may involve non-invasive tests that help identify unrecognized health issues.

questions.correct_answer: B. Screening tests are used to make definitive diagnoses and offer treatment plans.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Screening tests are used to make definitive diagnoses and offer treatment plans.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between exposure and a rare disease. The study involves selecting a cohort of individuals, and following them for a few years. Then it involves identifying cases of the disease from this cohort, comparing them to a control group from the same cohort. Which of the following statements about this type of study design is false?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a cohort study nested within a case-control study.

options.label: B
options.text: It maintains temporal association between exposure and outcome.

options.label: C
options.text: It is useful for studying rare diseases that require expensive diagnostic tests.

options.label: D
options.text: Recall bias is not a concern in this type of study.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a cohort study nested within a case-control study.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) It is a cohort study nested within a case-control study.

questions.text: A new antiseptic is tested using the Rideal-Walker method, and the coefficient obtained is lower than phenol's coefficient. Which of the following could explain this result?

options.label: A
options.text: The antiseptic is less effective at inhibiting bacterial growth compared to phenol.

options.label: B
options.text: The antiseptic is more toxic to human cells than phenol at equivalent concentrations.

options.label: C
options.text: The antiseptic is more effective in preventing bacterial spores from forming.

options.label: D
options.text: The antiseptic is chemically less stable than phenol, causing inaccurate results in the test.

questions.correct_answer: A. The antiseptic is less effective at inhibiting bacterial growth compared to phenol.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) The antiseptic is less effective at inhibiting bacterial growth compared to phenol.

questions.text: An outbreak of hemorrhagic fever is reported in rural India, with evidence suggesting endemic transmission. Which of the following viruses is most likely responsible for this outbreak?
A public health expert is analyzing the characteristics of measles in a community outbreak. Which of the following statements about measles is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Measles has a high secondary attack rate in susceptible populations.

options.label: B
options.text: Only one strain (serotype) of the virus causes measles infection worldwide.

options.label: C
options.text: Measles is not infectious during the prodromal stage of the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Natural infection with measles confers lifelong immunity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Measles is not infectious during the prodromal stage of the disease.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Measles is not infectious during the prodromal stage of the disease

questions.text: A couple has 4 children, all unvaccinated for Measles. A child got Measles on 5 August 2015. Two other children developed Measles by 15 August 2015. Secondary attack rate is:
A study is being conducted to analyze the most effective measures for controlling typhoid fever. Which of the following statements are accurate regarding typhoid disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The most important preventive measure against typhoid is immunization.

options.label: B
options.text: Safe water, proper sanitation, and good hygiene practices are more critical than immunization in reducing the burden of typhoid.

options.label: C
options.text: Drug resistance in typhoid fever is less problematic than drug resistance in tuberculosis.

options.label: D
options.text: In approximately 10% of cases, typhoid is transmitted from person to person.

questions.correct_answer: B. Safe water, proper sanitation, and good hygiene practices are more critical than immunization in reducing the burden of typhoid.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Safe water, proper sanitation, and good hygiene practices are more critical than immunization in reducing the burden of typhoid.

questions.text: During a cholera outbreak, several public health interventions are implemented to control the spread of the disease. Which of the following measures is not typically recommended?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing mass chemoprophylaxis to all individuals in the affected area.

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring proper disposal of excreta to prevent water contamination.

options.label: C
options.text: Chlorinating drinking water to eliminate the cholera pathogen.

options.label: D
options.text: Promptly identifying and treating cholera cases to reduce morbidity and mortality.

questions.correct_answer: A. Providing mass chemoprophylaxis to all individuals in the affected area.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Providing mass chemoprophylaxis to all individuals in the affected area.

questions.text: In a region where Japanese encephalitis is endemic, a public health official is planning a vaccination campaign. Which of the following statements about the Japanese encephalitis vaccine is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Booster doses should be administered after the first year and repeated every 3 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The vaccine is contraindicated for infants younger than 6 months of age.

options.label: C
options.text: Two primary doses are administered to children aged 1-3 years.

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccination is recommended for children aged 1-9 years in endemic regions.

questions.correct_answer: D. Vaccination is recommended for children aged 1-9 years in endemic regions.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Vaccination is recommended for children aged 1-9 years in endemic regions

questions.text: An epidemiologist is analyzing the severity and spread of plague in an outbreak. Which of the following indices is most crucial in determining the maximum explosiveness of plague transmission?
During an outbreak investigation, a physician suspects a case of endemic typhus. Which of the following organisms is the primary vector responsible for transmitting this disease?
Match the STD color-coded kits with their respective syndromes: Column A: White Grey Green Yellow Column B: Urethral/cervical discharge Genital ulcer disease Lower abdominal pain Vaginal discharge

A 5-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a dog bite from a street dog. On examination, the wound is an abrasion of 1.5 cm in size with slight oozing. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this wound are correct? Category 3 wound Wash the wound with soap and normal tap water for 15-20 minutes Clean the wound with spirit Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing Equine immunoglobulin is given at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice Intradermal vaccine is administered on days 0, 3, 7, and 28

A 40-year-old man from a rural area presents with a high fever, headache, and a characteristic rash that starts on his ankles and wrists and spreads centrally. The rash is characteristic of a tick bite. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing his symptoms?

A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of leprosy presents to the clinic for follow-up. The patient has been undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy, and the physician is assessing the disease's progression. In this context, the physician considers using the Lepromin test. For which of the following purposes is the Lepromin test most commonly utilized?

A 25-year-old man presents for a routine check-up. His blood pressure is measured, and it is noted to be lower than average for his age. Upon reviewing his medical history, it is found that he also had lower blood pressure during his childhood. This pattern of persistently lower blood pressure across his lifespan is referred to as:

A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a health check-up. The physician is assessing her obesity status using different obesity indices. Which of the following obesity indices does not factor in the patient's height when calculating the degree of obesity?

A 47-year-old male presents with a persistent fever lasting 3 weeks, unresponsive to antibiotics and anti-malarial medications. The patient also has abdominal distension. A diagnostic rk39 dipstick test is positive, indicating the likely presence of a parasitic infection. What would be the appropriate next step in management for this patient?

A public health officer is reviewing the goals and execution of the Mid-Day Meal Scheme, which is designed to ensure children have access to a nutritious meal during school hours. While the programme has clear objectives related to nutrition, certain aspects are often misunderstood. Which of the following is not aligned with the principles of the Midday School Meal Programme?

options.label: A
options.text: Should supply ½ of daily protein and ⅓ of daily calories

options.label: B
options.text: Is a substitute for regular food

questions.correct_answer: B. Is a substitute for regular food
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Is a substitute for regular food

questions.text: A population expert is analyzing a nation’s demographic transition, where the birth rate begins to decrease due to factors like increased access to contraception and improved female education. In which stage of the demographic transition does the contraction of the demographic gap usually begin?

India has a total fertility rate (TFR) of 1.94, which is close to the replacement level. The crude birth rate (CBR), which is a measure of the number of live births per 1,000 people in a population, is often influenced by the fertility rate. Given this information, what is the most likely crude birth rate (CBR) for India?

A newly married couple is consciously interested in using only natural family planning method for contraception. They are considering different options and want the most reliable one. Which of the following natural methods, is considered the most effective in preventing pregnancy?

A breastfeeding woman with an 18-month-old child presents with complaints of heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding. She is seeking an appropriate contraceptive method that will be compatible with breastfeeding and offer reliable contraception. Considering her current condition, which of the following is the best contraceptive option?

A 30-year-old woman has been using combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past 2 years. She is inquiring about the benefits of using OCPs beyond pregnancy prevention. Which of the following conditions are known to be positively impacted by the use of combined OCPs? Hepatocellular adenoma Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Ovarian cysts Fibrocystic disease of the breast Ectopic pregnancy
Pearl Index of 10 per HWY for a Contraceptive ‘C’ in a population. An average woman in this population is expected to have how many accidental pregnancies in her reproductive life span?

A 32-year-old man works as a heavy laborer and seeks advice on his daily energy and protein intake. Based on the new 2021 guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate estimate of his daily nutritional requirements?

A lactating mother, 3 months postpartum, is being counseled on her nutritional needs. According to the most recent guidelines, which of the following combinations of nutrients is necessary for a lactating woman to meet her energy and micronutrient needs while supporting breast milk production?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron: 23 mg/day, Folic Acid: 330 mcg/day, Calcium: 1200 mg/day, Vitamin A: 950 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day

options.label: B
options.text: Iron: 19 mg/day, Folic Acid: 300 mcg/day, Calcium: 1000 mg/day, Vitamin A: 840 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day

options.label: C
options.text: Iron: 23 mg/day, Folic Acid: 400 mcg/day, Calcium: 1200 mg/day, Vitamin A: 900 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day

options.label: D
options.text: Iron: 29 mg/day, Folic Acid: 570 mcg/day, Calcium: 1000 mg/day, Vitamin A: 900 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day

questions.correct_answer: A. Iron: 23 mg/day, Folic Acid: 330 mcg/day, Calcium: 1200 mg/day, Vitamin A: 950 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Iron: 23 mg/day, Folic Acid: 330 mcg/day, Calcium: 1200 mg/day, Vitamin A: 950 mcg/day, Vitamin D: 600 IU/day

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with spontaneous ecchymosis and recurrent nosebleeds. She mentions that she has recently experienced generalized weakness and swollen gums. Which vitamin deficiency is most strongly associated with these bleeding manifestations?

A public health expert is conducting an epidemiological study on the effects of fluoride contamination in drinking water. After evaluating the fluoride levels in the drinking water, it is found that residents with chronic exposure to fluoride in concentrations within a certain range are at risk for crippling fluorosis. Based on the available data, which of the following ranges of fluoride levels is most commonly associated with the development of this condition?
Match the following food (List I) with its respective nutrient in list II? List A Papaya fruit Soya beans Ragi Amla fruit List B Calcium Vitamin C Protein Vitamin A

A study is evaluating the effectiveness of long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) in malaria prevention. The nets are treated with pyrethroid insecticides and a chemical binder that enhances durability. What is the primary advantage of using LLINs over regular insecticide-treated bed nets (ITBN)?

options.label: A
options.text: LLINs use higher concentrations of pyrethroid insecticides, allowing for more immediate mosquito knockdown.

options.label: B
options.text: LLINs can withstand up to 20 washes, making them last longer (≥3 years) and maintain effectiveness.

options.label: C
options.text: LLINs are more effective against a wider range of mosquito species compared to ITBNs.

options.label: D
options.text: LLINs are designed for use in low-resource settings only and are not recommended for urban areas.

questions.correct_answer: B. LLINs can withstand up to 20 washes, making them last longer (≥3 years) and maintain effectiveness.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) LLINs can withstand up to 20 washes, making them last longer (≥3 years) and maintain effectiveness.

questions.text: In a study on a population's genetic variation, a scientist observes that allele frequencies remain stable over multiple generations. This stability suggests that there are no significant evolutionary forces acting on the population. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon, according to population genetics?

options.label: B
options.text: Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, indicating no evolution is taking place

options.label: C
options.text: Watson and Crick's model of DNA structure ensuring no genetic mutations

options.label: D
options.text: Weigert-Meyer rule, which focuses on the migration of alleles

questions.correct_answer: B. Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, indicating no evolution is taking place
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, indicating no evolution is taking place

questions.text: The S.T.A.R.T. system, is commonly used in mass casualty events. Which of the following statements best describes the application of this triage method?

options.label: A
options.text: It requires highly trained medical personnel to make critical decisions on the treatment of each patient.

options.label: B
options.text: It is intended for use only by physicians and advanced emergency medical responders.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be performed by laypeople and minimally trained personnel to rapidly assess and prioritize patients during emergencies.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves a detailed and lengthy assessment process to determine each patient's specific treatment needs.

questions.correct_answer: C. It can be performed by laypeople and minimally trained personnel to rapidly assess and prioritize patients during emergencies.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) It can be performed by laypeople and minimally trained personnel to rapidly assess and prioritize patients during emergencies.

questions.text: What is the Delphi method primarily used for in decision-making processes?

options.label: A
options.text: To make decisions in a single round by voting

options.label: B
options.text: To obtain reliable and creative exploration of ideas through expert consensus

options.label: C
options.text: To allow the facilitator to make decisions without input from the participants

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid using expert opinions and rely solely on statistical data

questions.correct_answer: B. To obtain reliable and creative exploration of ideas through expert consensus
questions.explanation: Ans. B) To obtain reliable and creative exploration of ideas through expert consensus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Shrivastava Committee (1975) are correct? It proposed the creation of Village Health Guides and Health Assistants as part of the community health workforce. It recommended a reorientation of medical education through the ROME scheme to focus more on primary health care. It called for the complete separation of family planning activities from malaria control activities. It emphasized the importance of creating Referral Service Complexes between PHCs and higher-level health centers.

Match the following management techniques with their primary functions and select the correct option: List I Cost Minimization Analysis (CMA) Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA) Cost Effectiveness Analysis (CEA) Planning Programming Budgeting System (PPBS) List II Compares the costs and benefits of an intervention in monetary terms using approaches like Human Capital and Willingness to Pay. Used to allocate resources efficiently by grouping activities related to each objective and ensuring financial resources align with planned goals. Compares the costs of interventions that provide equivalent benefits, aiming for the least-cost solution. Measures benefits in natural units such as life years gained, using health outcomes like heart attacks avoided or life expectancy.

Which of the following statements regarding the norms for health personnel are correct? The norm suggests 1 health worker (male or female) per 5000 population in plains and per 3000 in hilly regions. Trained Dais (TBAs) is recommended at a ratio of 1 per 1000 residents in villages. Pharmacists are recommended at a ratio of 1 per 5000 population. Anganwadi Workers (AWWs) are needed at a ratio of 1 per 300–800 residents in the plains.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are correct

questions.text: A health department is tasked with preparing for potential bio-terrorism threats. The department is most concerned with pathogens that are moderately easy to disseminate and can cause moderate morbidity but low mortality. Based on the provided classification of bio-terrorism agents, which of the following pathogens is the most likely candidate for such a scenario?

Which of the following statements regarding Multistage Random Sampling and Cluster Random Sampling are correct? Multistage Random Sampling involves selecting sampling units at each stage, where each unit is nested within the previous one. Cluster Random Sampling is primarily used when the population is organized into natural groups or clusters. Multistage Random Sampling is less flexible compared to Cluster Random Sampling, as it involves multiple steps with more control over the sample. Cluster Random Sampling allows comparison between clusters due to their homogeneity within themselves and heterogeneity between clusters.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above are correct

questions.text: The National Suicide Prevention Strategy (NSPS) recommends a specific approach to reduce suicide mortality in India by 2030. Which of the following best describes the key aspect of this strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus on improving national healthcare infrastructure and primary care only.

options.label: B
options.text: Introduction of the REDS framework to address suicide prevention.

options.label: C
options.text: Establishment of suicide prevention awareness only in educational institutions.

options.label: D
options.text: Focus on reducing stigma without strengthening the capacity of health services.

questions.correct_answer: B. Introduction of the REDS framework to address suicide prevention.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Introduction of the REDS framework to address suicide prevention.

questions.text: In a study comparing categorical data, the researcher needs a statistical test that does not assume the data is normally distributed. Which test is best suited for this scenario?

The concept of the germ theory of disease revolutionized microbiology and medicine. Which of the following discoveries validated this theory in 1876, particularly through the identification of a bacterium responsible for an infectious disease?

options.label: C
options.text: The identification of the anthrax bacillus

questions.correct_answer: C. The identification of the anthrax bacillus
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The identification of the anthrax bacillus

questions.text: A public health investigator is examining the impact of cholera in a region with a high number of deaths from other causes. In assessing the contribution of cholera to overall mortality, which of the following measures would be most appropriate?

In an epidemiological study aiming to investigate the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, data on the number of lung cancer cases is collected from a hospital while cigarette sales data for the same time period is also examined. Which bias is most likely to affect the findings of this type of study?

A 28-year-old woman wishes to use a natural method of contraception and is instructed on the Symptothermal method. Which of the following combinations of methods is part of the Symptothermal method of contraception?

options.label: A
options.text: Calendar method, basal body temperature, and cervical mucus method

options.label: B
options.text: Ovulation predictor kit, basal body temperature, and cervical mucus method

options.label: C
options.text: Fertility awareness method, calendar method, and basal body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: Basal body temperature, cervical mucus, and withdrawal method

questions.correct_answer: A. Calendar method, basal body temperature, and cervical mucus method
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Calendar method, basal body temperature, and cervical mucus method

questions.text: According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) 2022, which of the following health systems has the highest number of beds in relation to its defined norm?

A researcher is conducting a meta-analysis and needs to identify potential publication bias in the studies. The researcher is looking for a specific type of graph that represents individual studies and their precision. Which of the following would be the most appropriate tool to detect bias?

A 28-year-old man presents with a high fever, malaise, and hemorrhagic symptoms, including bleeding from the gums and blood in his stool. He was recently exposed to a tick while working in an agricultural field. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for his illness?
Identify the distribution shown by the Image 3?
What is not true about the given graph?

options.label: D
options.text: Its usually seen in smaller samples only

questions.correct_answer: D. Its usually seen in smaller samples only
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Its usually seen in smaller samples only

questions.text: Counselling and Screening is done for TB in a HIV positive patient at ICTC Centre (NACP program). This is which level of prevention?

A public health researcher analyzes the relationship between alcohol consumption and liver cirrhosis and finds that the attributable risk for liver cirrhosis due to alcohol consumption is 90%. This means that a significant portion of liver cirrhosis cases is directly linked to alcohol consumption. Based on this finding, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption

options.label: B
options.text: 90% of liver cirrhosis cases in the population can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in the population can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption

questions.text: In which of the following diseases is the human host considered a dead end?
A healthcare worker needs to verify whether a vaccine has been inadvertently frozen, which could affect its efficacy. Which of the following tests is used to identify a vaccine that has been frozen?

A screening test for breast cancer is applied to a population of 1,000 women. The test results show 150 positive cases and 850 negative cases. Among the 150 positive cases, 120 women are confirmed to have breast cancer by a diagnostic test, while 30 women are ruled out. Among the 850 negative cases, 50 women are found to have breast cancer. What is the sensitivity of the screening test?
Which of the following is not typically included in the manifestations of Congenital Rubella Syndrome?
A global health organization is evaluating indicators for malaria control in a high-burden country. Which of the following best describes the recent transmission?
Which of the following organisms does not require a vector for transmission?

A healthcare professional is educating patients about the potential consequences of HPV infection. Which of the following conditions can HPV infection lead to? Cervical cancer Anal cancer Oropharyngeal cancer Laryngeal papillomatosis
Which of the following best describes DALY?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of economic impact of a disease on a population

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of years of healthy life lost due to premature death or disability

options.label: C
options.text: A measure of healthcare costs associated with a particular illness

options.label: D
options.text: A measure of average life expectancy in a given population

questions.correct_answer: B. A measure of years of healthy life lost due to premature death or disability
questions.explanation: Ans. B) A measure of years of healthy life lost due to premature death or disability

questions.text: Correct statement about the Double histogram of Population pyramid shown is

options.label: A
options.text: Increased height means low life expectancy

options.label: C
options.text: Broad base represents High fertility and high dependency

options.label: D
options.text: Broad base means more working population

questions.correct_answer: C. Broad base represents High fertility and high dependency
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Broad base represents High fertility and high dependency

questions.text: A resident doctor sustains a needlestick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive symptomatic patient. What is the best regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for this resident doctor?
